Designing efficient catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition to reduce CO2 emission is one of crucial for environmental issues technology. Herein, the multiple-amino functionalized triazine-based polymer (MAFTP) was prepared through the nucleophilic reaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine and ethylenediamine by a conventional heating method, which are favorable for CO2 adsorption due to their nitrogen-rich structure. MAFTP was characterized entirely, the CO2 adsorption capacity of MAFTP showed the CO2 uptake performance with the values of 5.73 cm3 g −1 at 273 K and 1 bar. MAFTP/KI catalyst exhibited efficient catalytic activity for CO2 fixation to epoxides. 99 % propylene carbonate yield and 99 % selectivity were obtained under 120 °C, 2.0 MPa for 2.0 h without organic solvent. Additionally, the catalysts could be recycled easily from the products after reaction by centrifugation and then reused 5 times efficiently. Meanwhile, the catalytic activity of MAFTP/KI to other substituted epoxides was discussed. Moreover, DFT calculation was adopted to analyze the possible cycloaddition reaction mechanism. The MAFTP/KI system is a promising candidate for CO2 chemical fixation attributing to the low cost, abundant availability, easy separation and high catalytic activity for CO2 chemical fixation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Triazine-based polymer CO2 cycloaddition Cycle carbonates DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 fixation to commercial value product is a great contribution to environmental issues while CO2 is an abundant, obtainable, non-toxic C1 building block [1,2]. The catalytic conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates already attracts plenty of interest which is in accordance with atom-economical and green chemistry (Scheme 1 ). Cyclic carbonates have a wide application in electrolytes, glycols, polar aprotic solvents and pharmaceutical ingredients [3,4]. However, the CO2 molecule is thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness because the carbon atom in CO2 molecule is the highest oxidation valence state, causing the lowest energy state of CO2 [5]. Hence, various catalysts are prepared to reduce the energy barrier so that the reaction could be promoted smoothly [6]. Until now, plenty of endeavors have been concentrated on the development of high activity catalytic systems for CO2 cycloaddition. Various homogeneous catalysts have been developed, including ionic liquids (ILs) [7,8], metal salen [9,10], alkali metal salts [11,12], and so on. Although homogeneous catalysts have excellent catalytic activity, the separation of homogeneous catalysts from products goes against with the principle of “Green Chemistry” [13]. Thereafter, heterogeneous catalysts, which could be separated from products and reused easily, have been devoted to the exploitation, such as supported ionic liquids catalysts [14,15], metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [16,17], porous organic polymers (POPs) [18–20], and so on. Recently, non-metal catalysts are deserved because the drawback of metal loss and environmental harm cannot be ignored. Especially, POPs have excellent properties such as high specific surface area, permanent porosity, excellent physical and chemical stability, and tunable organic functional monomers. The properties of these POPs lead to better mass transfer, easier access to active sites and more uniform distribution of active sites, and they have great potential for adsorption and efficient conversion of CO2 [21,22]. Triazine derivatives, as one of the POP, have been widely studied with the property of CO2 affinity due to their nitrogen-rich structure. Although C = N-C-containing nitrogen heterocyclic molecules are the weakest of all amine molecules in terms of basicity, they are the best basic catalysts in the carbon dioxide cycloaddition to cyclic carbonates [23]. This is due to the fact that the catalytic reaction is not only related to substrate adsorption but also to product desorption. The rapid adsorption and desorption of carbon dioxide molecules are beneficial for the release of the active center. This is attributed to the fact that the conjugation of C =N-sp2 reduces the electron density in the nitrogen atom, making it less basic. This effectively weakened the force between the nitrogen atoms in C = NC and the carbon atoms in CO2, which accelerated the adsorption and desorption time of CO2. It is conducive to the enrichment of CO2 in the catalytically active site and the formation of intermediate transition state molecules by its addition with epoxide. For example, Thomas's team synthesized a high-performance polymer framework with regular and irregular porosity by the dynamic trimerization reaction, and the catalyst was applied in cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides [24]. Ali Coskun reported charged covalent triazine framework (cCTF) using cyanophenyl substituted viologen dication as a monomer via ionothermal trimerization reaction which had high specific surface area and high adsorption capacity for CO2 [25]. For the reaction of CO2 to epoxides, 99% PC was obtained under the optimum conditions of 1 MPa, 90 °C, 12 h. Besides, Hu adopted a Schiff base condensation reaction with melamine and aldehydes to synthesize versatile mesoporous organic polymers that were applied in CO2 fixation [26]. Although the above catalysts have good catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of CO2, harsh conditions in the catalyst preparation process limited their industrialization. Reportedly, substitution reaction of cyanuric chloride (CYC) can be operated because the Cl structure can be replaced by –NH2, –COOH, –OH [24,25]. Hence, we selected a mild condition to synthesis multiple amino functionalized triazine-based polymer (MAFTP) catalyst by a traditional method and applied in CO2 cycloaddition. Melamine and ethylenediamine (EDA) were chosen as substitutes which were used to substitute the Cl of cyanuric chloride to obtain MAFTP. The properties and texture of MAFTP were analyzed. MAFTP was adopted for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. Meanwhile, the effects of the reaction parameters (temperature, time, CO2 pressure, and catalyst loading) on the catalytic activity were investigated. Additionally, the reusability and catalytic activity to other substituted epoxides were investigated. At last, DFT calculation was employed to analyze the mechanism of catalytic reaction. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst characterization As illustrated in Fig. 1a , the multiple amino functionalized triazine-based polymer (MAFTP) catalyst was fabricated with MA and CYC via a common three-step method, the synthesized detail was depicted in Supporting Information. First, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were employed to explore the morphology features of MAFTP, the results were shown in Fig. 1b, Fig. 1c and 1d, respectively. As depicted, the MAFTP catalyst demonstrated a thin layered structure on the edges and stacking structure in the central region which are benefit for the CO2 cycloaddition due to the exposed active site. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was detected to analyzed the structure of MAFTP. As exhibited in Fig. 2a , MAFTP presented a two-dimensional sheet-like structure like carbon nitride (13.1°, 27.5°). The high intensity diffraction peak at 27.5° corresponds to the typical feature (002) interlayer stacking reflection of conjugated aromatic systems. Moreover, the weak peak at 13.1° corresponds to (100) and was interpreted as the in-plane structural repeating motif, probably due to the hole-to-hole distance of the consecutive tri-striazine pores [27]. Furthermore, FT-IR spectra were performed to compare the difference between MAFTP, CYC, and MA to illuminate the organic functionalities in the synthesis of the MAFTP catalyst (Fig. 2b). For MAFTP, the absorption bands at 3355 and 3267 cm−1 and the peak of 1681 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching and bending vibration of N–H bonds [1,28]. A blue shift emerged compared with the –NH2 of MA, which might be the introduction of the conjugation of the triazine ring. 2940 and 2875 cm−1 could be assigned to the C–H bond in –CH2CH2– [29]. The peaks at 1421 cm−1 and 1584 cm−1 were attributed to characteristic absorptions of the –C = N bond in triazine-rings [29]. The peak at 815 cm−1 was assigned to triazine-rings vibrations. Besides, the disappearance of the band at 850 cm−1 (C–Cl) suggested the completion of polymerization [30]. The MAFTP structure was also characterized by the solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy and the result was presented in Fig. 2c. The chemical shift peaks around 155−170 ppm were attributed to the C atom of the triazine ring [31]. In addition, the resonances at 63.62 ppm were attributed to the CH2NMe2 [32], whereas the carbon atoms adjacent to the N-atom resonated at 40.45 ppm [33]. Meanwhile, the unbranched alkyl chain is characterized by a quartet around 14.66 ppm [34]. Fig. 2d showed the full XPS spectra, which clarified the existence of C, N and O elements. In C 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 2e), the peak at 284.6 eV belonged to the sp2-hybridized carbon in the form of C–C, which was confirmed as standard carbon [35]. The 286.2 eV peak could be assigned to C–H [36]. The peak at 288.6 eV was ascribed to the N–C = N of heterocycle aromatic structure, which was related to the major skeleton carbon in the triazine-based heterocycle [35]. Moreover, the N 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 2f) possessed three peaks. The sp2 bonded nitrogen in C–N = C was located at 398.5 eV, the –NH– peak was observed at 399.6 eV [1,3,37] and the –NH2 peak was observed at 400.7 eV [38]. The surface area and porosity of MAFTP were tested by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K (Fig. 3a ). MAFTP exhibited type Ⅳ adsorption isotherm behavior with H1 hysteresis loop, indicating the mesoporous feature of MAFTP. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of MAFTP was calculated to be 20 m2 g −1. This phenomenon might result from layer structure and stacking between layers and the BET surface area was caused by the chain structure. The heteroatom N-rich networks were prompted to measure the CO2 uptake capacity of the MAFTP, and CO2 uptake by MAFTP was found to be 5.73 cm3 g −1 (273 K, 1 bar). The basicity of the MAFTP catalyst was investigated through CO2-TPD experiments. CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. 3b) revealed three Gaussian peaks representing the weak (150 °C), medium (332 °C), and strong (420 °C) basic sites. The low-temperature peak corresponds to the CO2 desorption from weak basic sites, such as the triazine ring. The medium-temperature peak originates from medium basic sites, such as –NH–. The high-temperature peak is correlated to the desorption of strong base –NH2. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted to confirm the thermal stability of MAFTP. In Fig. 3c, the first descent with weight loss of 7.35 % below 100 °C was attributed to the desorption of adsorbed water. MAFTP had favorable stability below 208 °C which could meet the application requirements for CO2 cycloaddition. 2.2 Screening of cocatalyst The catalytic activity of MAFTP was examined over the model cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide (PO), the results were listed in Fig. 4 . Previous literatures had indicated that triazine ring structure possessed low cycloaddition catalytic activity when catalysts were used alone in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides [39,40]. To enhance the catalytic activity, cocatalysis was widely added because the process was convenient, simple and effective. In this work, due to the lack of nucleophiles in the MAFTP, it was necessary to add a halogen-containing compound as a cocatalyst, including KCl, KBr, KI, NH4Cl, NH4Br, NH4I, TBAB, TBAI were discussed. When MAFTP or KI was used separately, there was only 4.6 % and 4.1% PC yield were obtained, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4, I – exhibited the highest catalytic activity in the presence of the same cation, because I– owns the best leaving ability compared to Br– and Cl–. Comparing KI with NH4I and TBAI, the synergistic effect of KI was more obvious than NH4I and TBAI which the result of the electrostatic effect of K +[38,41]. Hence, 150 mg MAFTP and 0.6 mmol KI was selected as the model catalyst in the following experiments. 2.3 Effects of reaction parameters As described in Fig. 5a , the PC yield increased to almost 100 % rapidly within 2 h. Hence, 2 h was the optimum reaction time. Similarly, the effect of temperature on PC yield was also examined. As depicted in Fig. 5b, when the temperature ranged from 80 °C to 120 °C, the PC yield raised from 14 % to 99 %. Thus, 120 °C was selected as the optimum temperature. Subsequently, the effect of CO2 pressure on PC yield was also discussed (Fig. 5c). PC yield increased with the increase of CO2 pressure under 2 MPa. When CO2 pressure came to higher than 2 MPa, a lower PC yield was obtained. Resulting from higher CO2 concentration could accelerate the reaction in the low-pressure region, while higher CO2 concentration could dilute the PO concentration [20,42]. In order to better verify the effect of pressure on reaction performance, the performance tests were conducted with 0.2 MPa intervals between 2 and 3 MPa, as shown in following Figure S1. It can be seen from Figure S1 that there is a significant decrease in the PC yield when increasing to 2.5 MPa. However, when the pressure was increased from 2.5 to 3 MPa, the PC yield also decreased but not particularly significantly. As reported in the literature [20], the CO2 concentration is too high with increasing pressure in a vessel of a certain volume, resulting in a decrease of the PO concentration, so the PC yield decreases. Hence, appropriate CO2 concentration can maximize the yield of reaction products, and 2 MPa CO2 pressure could be the best choice. Finally, the influence of catalyst loading was also investigated and the results were shown in Fig. 5d. When the catalyst amount increased from 50 mg to 150 mg, PC yield varied from 34.4 % to 99.9 %. Nevertheless, the further increase in the dosage of catalysts did not make a significant increase in the PC yield. Herein, 150 mg MAFTP amount seemed to be the optimal catalyst loading. For comparison, several similar reported catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides are summarized in Table 1 . The comparative results showed that MAFTP/KI catalyst system exhibited enhanced catalytic activity under similar conditions. 2.4 Reusability of MAFTP The recyclability of MAFTP/KI was investigated to illuminate the potential applications in the industry. In order to verify that the efficiency is not affected by the reduction or reuse of KI, the catalyst is cleaned with ethyl acetate ultrasonic for many times in each recovery to ensure that there is no KI. Hence, KI was supplemented in every cycle in the catalyst cycling experiments. As shown in Fig. 6a , the MAFTP/KI catalytic system could be reused 5 times. There was only a slight PC yield decrease which was ascribed to the loss of catalyst amount in the recycling process. Hence, in the 6th run, PC yield reached 90 % with 10 mg fresh MAFTP added. Besides, FT-IR, XRD and TGA measurements were carried out to analyze the structure of the spent MAFTP, and the results were listed in Fig. 6b-d. Compared to the fresh MAFTP, the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 6b) of spent MAFTP did not change obviously, the newly formed peak around 1750 cm−1 could be assigned to stretching vibration of C = O in residual PC [20,52]. As shown in Fig. 6c, the XRD pattern performed unnoticed change. Furthermore, TGA curves (Fig. 6d) possessed a slight difference, which might be caused by the existence of residual PC. All those results deduced the robustness of MAFTP structure. 2.5 Catalytic activity towards other epoxides The general applicability MAFTP/KI under CO2 (2 MPa) at 120 °C for 2 h was also surveyed, and the yield (selectivity) were presented in Fig. 7 . And 99% PC yield was obtained under the above-mentioned reaction conditions. The product yield of BO could reach 47 % (90 %) within 2 h, and 90 % (92 %) yield within 3 h. The halide substituted epoxides (ECH) exhibited excellent yield under the same conditions resulting from the existence of the electron-withdrawing group. For AGE, BGE and SO, the yield of cyclic carbonate product was lower than PC ascribed to the steric hindrance of side-chains [53]. CHO exhibited the lowest reactivity under 120 °C, 2 MPa for 6 h, attributed to the special two rings structure [52]. 2.6 Computational insight into the catalytic mechanism DFT calculation was adopted to analyze the catalytic reaction mechanism, and the details were given in DFT calculations part of SI. Firstly, the equilibrium structures of MAFTP and propylene oxide (PO) were optimized, and the optimized structures were listed in Figure S1. Based on the optimized structures, the adsorption energy of MAFTP to PO was obtained for different sites, and the results were concluded in Table 2 . Reactive site 8 possessed the highest adsorption energy, herein, the reactive site of MAFTP with PO was 8 (–NH– group, which bridges the two triazine rings). Furthermore, the dual descriptor potential analysis for MAFTP, propylene epoxide and CO2 were also given in Fig. 8 . Clearly, PO was easily reacting with the yellow isoplane, and CO2 was easily reacting with the blue isoplane of the MAFTP. The reactive site number could be contrasted in Figure S1. Based on those results, the initial reaction structure (Fig. 9 ) was established. Firstly, the ring-opening reaction of PO (C55–O54 bond breaking), as well as the electrophilic reaction of CO2 (C49–O54 bonding) were conducted, and a Gibbs free energy barrier of 49.86 kcal mol−1 was observed (TS1). Then, the Int1 showed the formation of I53–C55 and C49–O54 bond, dihedral angle (O54C57C55I53) was 59.2° Next, TS2 was the transition state of I53 atom, the dihedral angle (O54C57C55I53) was 119.5°, and a free energy barrier of 30.22 kcal mol−1 was observed. Furthermore, Int2 was obtained by the rotation of I53, and the dihedral angle (O54C57C55I53) changed to 161.6° Notably, TS3 exhibited the reaction between the O51 and C55, as well as the leaving of I53 from C55. Expectedly, a free energy barrier of 30.22 kcal mol−1 was gained. Ultimately, the product was obtained and the catalyst was regenerated. Fig. 10 revealed that the Gibbs free energy barrier was 49.86 kcal/mol for the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO catalyzed by MAFTP/KI catalyst. The rate-determining step was the ring-opening reaction of PO and the insertion of CO2, this phenomenon was consistent with the pioneering works [54,55]. The DFT calculation illuminated that the PO was activated by the –NH– group, which bridges the two triazine rings, and the CO2 was activated by the amino group of terminal alkyl chain. Meanwhile, I– exhibited synergistic effect to accelerate the catalytic reaction. 3 Conclusions Multiple-amine functionalized triazine-based polymer (MAFTP) was prepared via a simple substitution reaction because of its nitrogen-rich structure, and the structure of MAFTP was characterized thoroughly. Then the catalytic activity of MAFTP cooperated with KI for CO2 cycloaddition into cyclic carbonates under solvent-free conditions was also conducted, 99% PC yield and outstanding selectivity were obtained under the temperature of 120 °C for 2 h. The MAFTP catalyst also exhibited excellent structural stability, which could be reused 5 times without obvious PC yield loss, and excellent substrate universality towards many epoxides. Ultimately, DFT calculation was adopted to discuss the reactive site between MAFTP/KI and reactants, as well as the mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The DFT calculation illuminated that the PO was activated by the –NH– group, which bridges the two triazine rings, and the CO2 was activated by the amino group of terminal alkyl chain. coredata.dc:description: Designing efficient catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition to reduce CO2 emission is one of crucial for environmental issues technology. Herein, the multiple-amino functionalized triazine-based polymer (MAFTP) was prepared through the nucleophilic reaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine and ethylenediamine by a conventional heating method, which are favorable for CO2 adsorption due to their nitrogen-rich structure. MAFTP was characterized entirely, the CO2 adsorption capacity of MAFTP showed the CO2 uptake performance with the values of 5.73 cm3 g −1 at 273 K and 1 bar. MAFTP/KI catalyst exhibited efficient catalytic activity for CO2 fixation to epoxides. 99 % propylene carbonate yield and 99 % selectivity were obtained under 120 °C, 2.0 MPa for 2.0 h without organic solvent. Additionally, the catalysts could be recycled easily from the products after reaction by centrifugation and then reused 5 times efficiently. Meanwhile, the catalytic activity of MAFTP/KI to other substituted epoxides was discussed. Moreover, DFT calculation was adopted to analyze the possible cycloaddition reaction mechanism. The MAFTP/KI system is a promising candidate for CO2 chemical fixation attributing to the low cost, abundant availability, easy separation and high catalytic activity for CO2 chemical fixation.
